newsitem.title: USA: Investors snub TIPS as U.S. deficit shrinks.
newsitem.headline: Investors snub TIPS as U.S. deficit shrinks.

text.p: The Treasury Department's new darlings -- inflation-linked notes floated last January -- have fallen prey to bullies on Wall Street as a shrinking federal deficit and low inflation make the securities weaklings, analysts and traders said on Thursday.

The 10-year notes were originally called TIPS, an acronym for Treasury Inflation Protected Securities, but frustrated dealers battling an illiquid market soon came up with their own creative labels. None of them are very nice.

"TIPS stands for Totally Illiquid Pieces of Shit," said one governments trader, who asked not to be quoted by name and wanted to bet the securities would no longer be offered five years from now. "Someone has to make some money off them somehow," he said.
Others simply reversed the acronym TIPS to SPIT, saying that was what the securities were worth.
Since the notes appeal mostly to retirees trying to preserve their nest eggs on inflation-adjusted terms, another dealer called TIPS buyers "buy, hold and die" investors.

"We've seen very, very low customer demand. What there is is of a very limited variety and not enough to justify the amount of issuance the Treasury is trying to do in this type of program," a trader at a major U.S. investment bank said.

In defense of the securities, Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary Roger Anderson told Reuters he believes the securities will lower borrowing costs -- saving taxpayers' dollars -- and that liquidity will improve with time.
"We view the development of the index securities market as a long-term project. We didn't expect them to be the investment of choice for absolutely everybody overnight," Anderson said.
Economists opposed to the securities said TIPS endanger the liquidity and flexibility of the Treasury bill and coupon markets as they take a small piece out of a shrinking pie.
Friday's pact between President Bill Clinton and Congressional Republicans to balance the books by 2002 heightened concern over a dwindling pool of government debt.

"TIPS is to remind you this is the tip of the iceberg. It is a big problem and we want to be sure it isn't something that sinks liquidity and the rest of the Treasury market," said Robert Brusca, chief economist at The Nikko Securities Co International Inc.
Anderson said this year the Treasury has cut back its supply of two- and three-year bills and notes, but the impact of the index-linked notes on supply so far is unclear.
"It's hard to say -- some of it has been due to index securities and some of it has been due to the shrinking deficit (which) has caught us by surprise," he said.
Economists accused the Treasury of issuing TIPS for political, not cash flow, reasons and said the timing was poor as inflation was near its modern lows at the date of issuance.

"If you look at the government auction, TIPS are not really necessary from an issuance standpoint. The Treasury is doing it for political reasons to try to give an inflation gauge and people aren't trading TIPS issues," said Michael Strauss, chief economist at Sanwa Securities (USA) Inc.
Nations typically issue price-linked securities when inflation is habitually high or above trend as a way of betting price growth will slow and validating political calls for less inflation.

However, when TIPS debuted last January 29, the Consumer Price Index (CPI) showed inflation at roughly 3.3 percent compared to one year earlier, well below the 25-year average of 4.0 percent, economists said. As of March, the CPI had fallen to 2.8 percent.

Foreign investors and central banks, which account for a large chunk of Treasury bill and coupon sales, have shown little interest in TIPS due to lack of liquidity, relatively wide spreads, and inability to speculate, analysts said.

"You are never going to convince foreigners to buy TIPS the way they buy Treasuries. They need liquidity and with the deficit the way it is, you won't be able to issue TIPS in the amounts needed," the U.S. investment bank dealer said.
Also worrying investors was recent speculation about the veracity of CPI-U (urban consumers) as a measure of price growth as TIPS are linked to the index.
A commission headed by Stanford University professor Michael Boskin concluded last December that CPI overestimates consumer inflation by about one percentage point annually.
Also, in April the Labor Department began trials on a new experimental geometric mean calculation.
Anderson said the market "just has to accept" any technical or professional change in the CPI-U. The formation of other inflation indices would have no effect, he added.
Experts said TIPS could go the way of now-defunct FICO bonds, issued during the savings and loan crisis in the late 1980s, and the old seven- and 20-year Treasury auctions.

Nikko's Brusca said his advice to the Treasury would be: "Don't try to use these as a major source of funding and don't ruin the liquidity in the coupon market to these things which are not worth their own name spelled backwards."
